procstep.procdesc:
Live tree diameters were extracted from existing datasets.
Blodgett Exp. Forest plots: Time period: 1984 to 2015. Source form: Excel workbook (Rob York, UC Berkeley). Area: Blodgett Exp. Forest, California. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
USFS Common Stand Exam plots: Time period: 2012 to 2014. Source form: Access database (Clark Richter, USFS). Area: California. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
USFS Forest Inventory and Analysis Plots: US Forest Service. Time period: 2001 to 2017. Source form: Access database (https://www.fs.fed.us/pnw/rma/fia-topics/inventory-data/). Area: California. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
NPS Fire Effects plots at Yosemite: National Park Service. Time period: 2007 to 2017. Source form: FFI, Access database (http://www.frames.gov/partner-sites/ffi/ffi-home). Area: Yosemite National Park. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
North/Central Sierra Nevada Fire and Fire Surrogates plots: Time period: 2003 to 2014. Source form: Excel workbook (Brandon Collins, UC Berkeley). Area: Blodgett Exp. Forest, El Dorado County, California. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
Sierra Nevada Forest Dynamics Plot Network: Time period: 2011 to 2014. Source form: Access database (Adrian Das, USGS). Area: Yosemite National Park. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).
Teakettle Exp. Forest plots: Time period: 2011. Source form: Excel workbook (Malcolm North, USFS). Area: Teakettle Exp. Forest, California. Contribution: Plot location, tree status, tree size (DBH).

Tree diameters were screened and corrected for unlikely growth rates where needed using the following method: We measured stem diameter twice in the summer of 2002 for 439 trees at a single site (LOLOG) in Sequoia National Park. Absolute discrepancies (AD) in the diameter measurements were modeled as a linear function of DBH, best fitted as AD = 0.0035 x dbh + 0.2032. For the lower growth limit, we removed negative growth measurements where the second diameter measurement was more than four times smaller than the potential measurement error given the AD relationship. For the upper limit of growth, we fit a gamma distribution to 243679 annual growth ring measurements from common species collected in mixed conifer forests of the central and southern Sierra Nevada. From the gamma distribution, only approximately 0.1% of annual ring widths were > 9 mm/yr. Observations of radial growth beyond the upper and lower limits were likely due to measurement or data recording errors. Once diameter measurement errors were identified, they were removed and diameters were interpolated from earlier and later diameter observations. If observation lengths of an individual stem were too short to allow interpolations, zero growth was assumed.
Tallies of live trees were made per plot, relative to plot size, yielding trees per hectare.
Sums of live tree basal area was made per plot, relative to plot size, yielding basal area per hectare.
Common fields across datasets were combined.
